awd_titl_txt: Conference: Cal-Bridge Summer Institute Alumni Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California Santa Cruz will organize and host the Cal-Bridge Summer Institute Alumni Conference, July 16-23, 2023. Participants will be doctoral students who are alumni of Cal-Bridge, a partnership between the University of California (UC) and the California State University (CSU) systems. Cal-Bridge was designed to provide pathways into research and the professorate for historically underrepresented students. During this summer program the learning community will focus on how people learn and on evidence-based teaching practices. The group will continue with regular virtual meetings throughout the academic year to promote the exchange of ideas and best practices. This award will cover the workshop costs for former Cal-Bridge students who are doctoral students at non-UC campuses.  

The Cal-Bridge Summer Institute, a series of professional development workshops, will have two major thrusts: 1) developing effective pedagogues, and 2) developing effective research leaders. In addition to these, the conference will include a variety of shorter professional development mentorship sessions, and community and cohort building activities. This conference aims to address two systemic points of loss along the professorial and professional researcher pathway for Cal-Bridge alumni currently in PhD programs outside of the University of California system: completion of the PhD, and entrance into the workforce. Specifically, the award will: 1) Broaden the impact of the professional development being offered to a larger group of doctoral scholars from diverse backgrounds, and 2) Provide space for Cal-Bridge Doctoral students to hold discussions and activities to build up their professional network and community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In July 2023 at the University of California, Santa Cruz, the first cohort of 32 Cal-Bridge Doctoral Scholars gathered for a week-long conference: the inaugural Cal-Bridge Summer Institute (CB SI). This cohort consists of Ph.D. students in astronomy, physics, and computer science from across the country, where 21 students are from University of California campuses and 11 are from non-UC universities. This Conference Grant fully supported the expenses for the attendance of 32 Doctoral Scholars, all who are alumni from the Cal-Bridge (undergraduate) Program and alumni from California State University campuses in their physics and astronomy departments and mathematics departments (the accompanying image shows all the doctoral student attendees and some Cal-Bridge leadership). 


PI Rodriguez Wimberly, Co-I Hood, and Cal-Bridge Co-Director Prof. Sara Callori attended the SI to facilitate 3 days of pedagogy workshops. Co-Is Rudolph and Schumm attended the SI leading fruitful discussions with the scholars regarding the new program. PI Rodriguez Wimberly and Senior Personnel Bracks led multiple workshops on community building, networking, and peer mentorship. The consultancy group Vitae UK led research leadership workshops. The week-long conference provided Doctoral Scholars 3 types of activities: (1) dedicated network building activities; (2) 3 full days of pedagogy workshops, where topics included (a) "How People Learn", (b) bottlenecks and threshold concepts, (c) teaching and learning concepts, (d) active learning techniques, (e) types of questions, and (f) concept mapping; and (3) 1.5 days of researcher professional development, where topics included (a) how to engage in professional development, and (b) how to be an effective researcher. Two community building events were also hosted during the week: (1) on the Santa Cruz Boardwalk where scholars, leadership, and staff communed over barbeque and strengthened relationships through carnival games and rides and (2) a Cal-Bridge undergraduate program scholar and alumni beach day closed out the inaugural SI. There were literal tears from many beach day attendees about how special the Cal-Bridge community is, the strength we give one another, and the paths we are creating not only for ourselves but mostly for the folks coming up behind us (current and aspiring STEM students who are primarily from historically underrepresented groups in STEM). The community building events proved to be as crucial to the success of the SI as the excellent professional development activities.


Last Modified: 07/15/2024
Modified by: Maria K Wimberly
